awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Environmentally Sustainable Manufacturing Technology for Fabrication of Radio Frequency (RF) Filter Products
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to develop a radio frequency (RF) network miniaturization technology and manufacturing methodologies to dramatically reduce the size, weight, and cost of RF filters. This research will develop special filters for a broad range of wireless applications, including smartphones and their infrastructure, WiFi devices, broadcast systems, and satellite systems. The proposed technology may reduce landfill contributions by over 300 tons, scrap metal by 2200 tons, and general metal consumption by 4500 tons.  

This SBIR Phase I project seeks to demonstrate the feasibility of the world’s first RF filter network miniaturization in air using an new network fractionalization algorithm via simulation and prototype fabrication. The fractionalization algorithm overcomes the high challenging wavelength barrier to RF filter miniaturization in air for development of miniature multilayer air filter structures. This project will develop: (1) methods of manufacture for single resonator circuit layer assemblies, the main building blocks for construction of multilayer air filter structures; (2) manufacturing methodologies for structures comprising multiple single resonator circuit layer assemblies to fabricate multi-resonator miniature multilayer air filter prototypes to demonstrate performance and key attributes of the multilayer air filter technology at various frequencies and power levels. The prototypes will be used to demonstrate the scalability, repeatability, and reproducibility of the miniature multilayer air filters for mass volume production, as well as to establish production unit cost models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Dynamac Microwave has successfully completed development of its proposed sustainable miniature multilayer radio frequency (RF) filter design and manufacturing technology in air dielectric medium for commercial development of Multilayer-Air filter products and solutions. Phase I R&D effort has led to successful proof of concept demonstration of FEFA (Fractional Element Filter Architecture) algorithm for miniaturization of RF filters in air dielectric medium and multilayer implementation for integrated filter product design, assembly, and fabrication.  New capabilities and performance features that are by far superior than previously projected/expected have been achieved and demonstrated. These include miniaturization percentage reaching 95%, weight reduction exceeding 80%, passband insertion loss reduction  reaching 0.3 dB or more than 50% signal power transfer efficiency improvement for 5G network infrastructure applications, high skirt selectivity exceeding 70 dB within close proximity of operating bandwidth providing improved spectrum efficiency, and enabling surface mount packaging technology for high power RF filter applications totally eliminating bulky, expensive, and performance degrading RF connectors.

For proof of concept and technology demonstration, numerous engineering prototypes including single-section FEFA Multilayer-Air filter building blocks and multi-section FEFA Multilayer-Air filters covering VHF, UHF, 800 MHz and 900 MHz range  were designed, developed, fabricated, and measured. Photo etching, laser cut sheet metal and sheet metal stamping technologies were used for fabrication of FEFA Multilayer-Air filter prototypes totally eliminating expensive CNC machining. Multi-section FEFA Multilayer-Air filter prototypes also successfully demonstrated elimination of labor intensive manual tuning, an expensive process used for manufacturing of current medium and high power RF filters.

The large and unprecedented miniaturization percentage achieved by FEFA algorithm and fractionalization of filter network elements directly results into significant reduction in raw material consumption and waste as well as improving RF performance by reducing passband insertion loss. Based on weight comparison between multi-section FEFA Multilayer-Air filter prototypes and current commercial CNC machined air cavity RF filters, reduction in metal consumption exceeded 80% with volume reduction exceeding 95%. Similarly, reduction in filter passband insertion loss demonstrated by FEFA filters exceeded 50% using engineering prototypes and electromagnetic (EM) structure simulation. Reduction in insertion loss leads to more efficient RF filters which in turn reduce electricity consumption and waste in wireless devices and communications equipment particularly in 5G network systems. Currently, due to its high insertion loss, RF filter is a major culprit responsible for energy waste in 5G network systems.  The ultra-low insertion loss performance demonstrated by FEFA Multilayer-Air RF filter technology in Phase I will reduce energy waste caused by current RF filter technologies in 5G network systems by more than 50%.  With millions of 5G network systems in planning for deployment, FEFA Multilayer-Air RF filter technology will be a key enabler for energy savings and carbon footprint reduction efforts for 5G infrastructure system manufacturers and cellular service providers.  

Substantial effort was also devoted to FEFA network synthesis as well as advanced complex filter network and EM structure modeling and simulation. Complex simulations based on FEFA Multilayer-Air EM structure models were performed for broadband WiFi and 5G n78 band and satellite backhaul filters covering multiple frequency bands from 3.5 GHz to 84 GHz based on confidential product specifications from our key target customers under non-disclosure agreements.

Due to successful customer discovery effort and significant interest shown in the proposed FEFA Multilayer-Air filter technology by our key target customers, Phase I project was substantially broadened to include important technical discussions and collaborations with key target customers. Our key target customers include the leading global manufacturers and market leaders in semiconductor device technology, 5G infrastructure equipment, and satellite launch and payload engineering technology which have confirmed significant strategic value of FEFA Multilayer-Air filter technology for their technology products and solutions.  These discussions also enabled Dynamac Microwave to refine and closely align its Phase I engineering prototype development and EM simulation plan and design strategy with applications and requirements from these major device and system manufacturers. Non-disclosure agreements have been signed with these manufacturers for exchange of confidential and proprietary technology information and product specifications setting the stage for early successful adoption of FEFA Multilayer-Air filter technology for large scale insertion into 5G infrastructure, WiFi transceiver/processor chip, and satellite backhaul applications, etc. enabling the company to push forward with commercial product development and volume manufacturing roadmap.

The proposed FEFA Multilayer-Air filter technology developed in Phase I represents a new class of RF filters that are small, lightweight, low loss, low cost, scalable, and sustainable. A unique set of value added benefits from a single filter technology never before possible providing the opportunity to build a US centric developer and manufacturer of FEFA Multilayer-Air filters for the fast growing multibillion dollar global RF filter market.

In summary, we believe FEFA Multilayer-Air filter design and manufacturing technology developed in Phase I represents a case where the right technology is in the right place at the right time.  

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2023
Modified by: Michael Ghadaksaz
